div.head: SUDAN GOVERNMENT RAILWAYS.
div.p: EXPRESS SERVICE FROM NOVEMBER 1ST, UNTIL FURTHER NOTICE.

‡Sleeping and Dining Cars. From Nov. 1st sleeping and dining cars on Egyptian State Railways are attached to ordinary trains from Cairo on Mon., Wed., and Sat. at 3 p.m. and from Luxor on Tues., Thurs. and Sun. at 5.30 p.m.- From 2nd Dec. Luxe trains with sleeping and dining. Cars will run on same days leaving Cairo and Luxor at 6.30 p.m. Early in January these trains will be run daily. Express between Shellal and Halfa carry mails and 1st class passaengers only, but 2nd class passengers may be accepted if accomadation is available. Express steamers do not stop at any stations on either up or down journeys between Shellal and Halfa. To insure accommodation official passengers must have warrants stamped "Accommodation Available" by Sudan Agent, Cairo, or Civil Secretary, Khartoum. A specially fitted barge with 1st and 2nd class accommodations for native ladies will be attached to these steamers. There will be a restaurant on these mail steamers.

div.head: Cyprus Government Railway.
div.p: The Limassol S.S. Co. steamers with good passenger accommodation run between Cyprus & Egypt as follows:—

Trains run alongside the steamers on the quay, and passengers can be conveyed to Famagusta, Nicosia, Morphou and intermediate stations. Good hotel accommodation for tourists is provided at Famagusta, at the Savoy Hotel (Mr. Najem Houry proprietor). Olympus Hotel, Mount Troodos, 6000 ft. above the sea. Magnificent Scenery. Perfect climate. Season May to end of October. For information apply to Mr. Najem Houry, Managing Director of Cyprus Hotel Co., Army Contractor, Limassol, Cyprus. There is a good carriage road from Kopia (on Railway) to Troodos. At Famagusta may be seen the fine old Latin Cathedral (now a mosque) begun in 1300 and finished in 1312, together with other ancient ruins and the Venetian fortifications, the finest in the world. Also the tower or palace, the scene of "Othello'' and of Ford's "Lover's Melancholy.'' The climate of Cyprus in the winter months is delightful and the Island will well repay a visit.
Information as to tickets, trains, etc., may be obtained of Messrs. Thomas Cook & Son, Egypt, or from the General Manager Railways, Famagusta. G. BERT DAY, General Manager. 29248—31-12-907

div.head: THE SUDAN REPORT FOR 1906
div.p: "The Egyptian Sudan covers an area of 950,000 square miles-that is to say it is more than twice as big as France and Germany together. Of this past extent of country, only about 1,876 square miles are cultivated. The remainder consists of desert, ramp and primaeval forest."

Such is the description of the Sudan with which Lord Cromer prefaces his remarks on the general conditions of the country in the report of 1906 which has been recently issued, but the next remarks are of a more comforting nature for we read that the area of cultivation has increased by 303,770 seres from 1905 to 1906, and that there was also an increase of over 9,000 in the area of land, brought under artificial irrigation

The greatest difficulty which the Administration of the Sudan has to deal with in the lack of labour, for the demand for even unskilled labour far exceeds the supply, and though the training of the younger inhabitants will doubtless do much to reduce the difficulty as time goes on, in the meantime it is a serious draw back to the rapid development of the country, as it must be many years before sufficient boys have been trained to dope with the ever increasing demand

As soon as the bridge which has already been commenced over the Nile between Khartoum North is complete, it is proposed to construct a railway up the middle of Ghezira and so form an outlet for produce from this province to stations on the White and Blue Niles.

The question of transport is of course one of the most important, as without quick means of pouring agricultural and other products into the markets much of the value is necessarily lost, either by the increased cost which a longer transport by Camel or such means is bound to entail, or else by depreciation in the goods themselves, therefore it would seem that the loan of a quarter of a million which the Badan Government has obtained in order to build the bridge was certainly well advised, and likely to meet with almost immediate returns

The conclusions arrived at by the Government as regards the cotton fields of the Sudan are somewhat disappointing the following remarks by Mr. Ernest Bonus, Director of Lands and Agriculture will clearly show: - "The prospects of Egyptian cotton in the Sudan appear not to be very brilliant in the immediate future. In the Province of Halfa, a European cultivator finds it is not a sufficiently successful crop, while the natives will not take trouble enough with it and have is one to instruct them. In Dongols, it is found that, for the present at any rate, the growing of cereals is more remunerative, though some individual cultivators might apparently succeed. In the Blue Nile Province, not much result has been obtained, though the quality of what is grown is good. No great increase can be expected before some irrigation system is introduced, because the Egyptian plant can only be cultivated on wakieh land, which it occupies for eight months of the year, without producing anything in the way of torage for the sakieh cattle. The prices obtainable are also too low to encourage cultivation on a large scale for export, though small quantity, sufficient for the local market, pays well enough The Governor of the White Nile province reports some enterprise with Egyptian cotton, and the possibility of growing it in his province is shown by the results of 2 acres grown at Duem, which gave 17 1/2 to 20 kantars cach with only three artificial watering. In the Berber Province, the natives will not grow Egyptian cotton. The seed is expensive, losses from locusts and white ants are a deterrent, and the prions obtainable are not attractive. The low prices are probably due to the inferior quality of the erop, which is carelessly cultivated. The possibility of growing the crop is, nevertheless, shown by the fact that 8 acres on the Government farm produced 28 kantars of ginned cotton , but the risk is also made clear by the destruction by locusts of 17 acres (the whole ares attempted) in the Sudan Experimental Plantation Syndicate's land at Zeidab. In the Khartoum Province, an increase of about 400 acres is reported in the area under cotton, but freights are heavy, and though the local demand is increasing, it is not expected that next year will show further increase in the screage. In the meantime, Egyptian seed is in fact being imported. The impediments appear to be the cost of labour and freight. The latter might be reduced by ginning the cotton before dispatch but until the output is moob increased, no considerable ginning factory would pay its expenses, though a small plant might succeed in the meantime. A start in this direction has been made at the Gordon College ma branch of technical instruction. In the Sennar Province, the Governor arranged small cotton show which attracted 100 exhibits, several of which were of quite superior quality. The Governor has also set up a few small gins, which have worked successfully and must largely encourage the industry and facilitate such trade as at present exists. In the Kordofan, Mongalla, and Bahr-el-Ghazal Provinces, nothing is being done at present. In the Red Sea Province, a very good crop is expected at Tokar, where cotton growing is an old established industry. It is gratifying to note that the National Bank of Egypt has instituted a system of making advances to the cultivators on hypothecation of their crops, which secure the producers Against loss arising from dear money or artificially restricted prices. In Kassals, it is reported that there is an increased tendency towards the cultivation of Egyptian cotton, and the local supply of seed (6,417 rottolis) was exhausted. In most provinces, the native cotton continues to be grown to supply local requirements, and in some districts the production is sensibly increasing the White Nile Province, an increase of 1,310 acres is reported. In the Blue Nile Province, of the screnge is twice that of last year, and at Gallabat the demand and prices are good. These developments appear to be due to the high Nile and favourable rains.

div.head: Clzeh Zoological Gardens.
div.p: >An Egyptian Army band will benceforward play at she Gizech Zoological Gardens on Sunday afternoon and the Gizeh boys band on Friday afternoons. Three giraffes of the Zoo have been moved to a large new paddock, 155 metres in circummference

div.head: The Kahmal Guard.
div.p: The expenses of the Mahmal Guard for this year has been fixed to be I.E 8,565, sgaitat I.E. 3,009 Yor last year. The guard will be composed of half of the 4th Battalion under the command of a field officer, who is to be selected by the War Office.

div.head: Khartoum Water Supply.
div.p: Water will be supplied at first in Khartoum only for the purpose of sprinkling the streets and watering the trees and public gardens. The water will not be distributed for use by the residents until it has undergone a through chemical analysis, so as to ascertain its fitness for drinking purposes.

div.head: The Mariout Line.
div.p: A petition is being signed by a number of landowners at Ikingui-Mariout, addressed to De Martine Pasha, Director of the Daira Khassa. The petitioners beg that a service of trains should be run between Alexandris and that station and that all trains on the Khedivial line should stop there both going and coming.

div.head: Cook's New Nile Steamer.
div.p: Messrs Thos. Cook and Sons vew paddle steamer the ,"Egypt" was open to the inspection of the pubhe yesterday afternoon, and general admiration was expressed at her appearance and fittings. A band was in attendance apd played during the afternoon, and tea was served on the upper deck, which was crowded with visitors.

div.head: Balloon Asoent.
div.p: Yesterday afternoon Mr. Sergyos Qetotch-kine's elie balloon, of a capacity of 600 cubic metres when inflated, made an ascent at 426 p.m. from Rond-Point At 6 o'clock the balloon descended on the left bank of the Mahmoudieh canal in a field under cultiation. The occupants were assaulted violently, on reaching the earth, by irate natives who had to be driven away by the police.

div.head: The Tour Eiffel.
div.p: The troupe now engaged by the Tour Eiffel management at Alexandria is meeting with great success Mime Valentino has gained much popularity by ber chatacteristic songs, which she renders in the true Parisian style, and the acrobatic feats of the Dao Dermotta are an especial attraction. Mile Manolita is now giving a new dance, the Japanese Doll, and on Wednesday we are to see the debut of the Dharvier troupe.

div.head: Omdurman Fire-Engine.
div.p: The two fire engines ordered for Omdarman arrived last week. One of them is a team engine of the style known as "Merryweather's Valiant". The other is workéd by hand, Mr Southgate, Superintendant of Police, Khartoum Province, has put them up, and they are now almost ready for use. A steam fire-engine, similar to the one recently brought to Omdurman, has been ordered for Khartouth. It will not be put into use, however, until the water-works are in full operation. This we understand, will be about one month hence.

div.head: Fregoli in Cairo.
div.p: The world-renowned Fregoli is at the Abbas Theatre in Cairo and we would recommend all those who bave not already see him to lose no time in doing so, and those who have been once will need no further inducement to repeat their visit, than they possess in the knowledge of the excellence of the entertainment, for if ever one man has held an audience spell bound for an entire evening Fregoli certainly did so last night, when for,the second time he appeared before the crowded house in the hundred and one characters whom he impersonates so well. It is impossible to choose any one character as being more perfectly played than another, for M. Pregoli is an artist to his finger tips, and the queraloas toves of the voluble elderly lady come as naturally to him as does the deep gromble of an itrate householder disturbed in his slambers by an imaginary burglar. Much of the success of the evening was also due to the manrer in which the orchestra acquitted themselves of the difficult task of following M: Bregoli through his ever changing moods, the accompaniment being almost buman in the various displays of the pleasure, dismay and anger which if was called upon to represent.

div.head: COUNCIL OF MINISTERS
div.p: At the Council of Miristers which was held under the presidency of the Khedive at the Abdin Palace on Saturday morning of the following decrees were approved--
The apporntment of Mr. Edward Bateson, Barrister at Law, London, appointed as Judge of the Native Tribunal at Keneh.
The appointment of Mobammed Tewfik Nessim Effendi, as 2nd Class Judge, at the Native Tribunal of the Ist Class Cairo
The substitution of a new plan of allotment of the Wakfs El Abmadi at Tantah.
The creation of two new cemetries in the Provinces of Menoufieh and Beni Suef.

div.head:
A SUDANESE SULTAN
TOMBORA AT KHARTOUM
div.p: The Sultan Tombora, of the Bahr el-Ghazal, who is on a visit to Khartoum was received by the Govenor-General on Friday week. He expressed his gratitude, for the kind treatment with which he has been treated, and for the numerous presents which have been bestowed upon him and his followers. He gave assurance of his loyalty to the Government and his readiness to comply with its instructions, and to rule his people in accordance with its regulations.

On Saturday week a dinner was given at the Omdurman Zabtieh in honour of Sultan Tombora and the other Sultans visiting Omdurman. Tombora was much pleased with the phonograph which supplied the music for the occasion

Sultan Tombora and his retinue, consisting of his son, his brother, his wives and about a dozen servants left Omdurman yesterday week returning to his country. He goes back carrying with him pleasant recollections of his short visit to these parts. He has evidently been very favourably impressed with what he witnessed here, and has expressed his desire to send four of his sons to Khartoam to be educated at Gordon College.
The "Sudan Times" says —
The Sultan's a very genial person. He speaks Arabic fairly well. Asked about his age he was not able to give a reply ; the Niams Niams

do not seem to have a regular way of measuring time. But by his looks one can judge that he is between fifty and sixty years old He states that when Zabeir Pasha was a young boy, and has no clear recollection of him.

Tombora has a large number of wives, exact number of whom he does not know ; nor does he seem to know the exact number of his children. But they are not less than fifty, a number of whom are already established as sheiths of different districts within his dominions. His successors as Sulton, will not be his oldest son, but one of his younger children whom he has designated an account of being more intelligent than the others, and hence more promising.

He says that the Niam Niams are no longer cannibals. Cannibalism was practiced by them in the past but on very rare ocassions. The people of a tribe never at the flesh of their own tribesmen. But when a man got old or helplessly sick, he was made a present of to another tribe which would feed upon his flesh, returning the favour to the former tribe when they had a similar opportunity.

div.head: INTRRNATIONAL HYGIENE, BUREAC.
div.p: London, Monday.

Dr. Ruffer has been appointed member of the committee for drafting regulations for the establishment in Paris of an international hygiene boreau. Great Britain and India are each entitled to six votes and Ibrahim Pasha states that Egypt is entitled to three votes.

div.head: NEW MACHINE GUN
div.p: Londonv, Monday.

Great interest has heen aroused in military circles by the extraordinary new machine gun invented by Major Fitzgerald, the Crimean veteran. The gun can be mounted anywhere under five minutes and has a range of 3.400 yards

div.head: THE KHEDIVE
div.p: The Khedive gave audience on Satarday morning to Si-Kbalil Bouhagib, husband of Princess Nazlé Hanem, who presented to the Khedive Si-Beshir Safar, Director of Wakfs at Tunis; Sir Eldon Gorst, who presented: the Rev. Molesworth ; Count Lavison ; Mohammed Tewfik Rifaat Bey, new Concillor of the native Court ot Appeal, who took the oath before his Highness prior fo assuming his functions and Mohammed Khelil Pasha, who tendered thanks for his promotion to the rank of Mirmiran. The Khedive arrived Inst nigh at Alexandria.

div.head:
PORTS AND LIGHTS.
TRIAL OP THE OFFICIALS.
div.p: The Native Criminal Court presented an unusually animated appearance this morning, when Judge Mohamed Bey Said took his seat on the bench to preside at the trial of the officials of the Ports and Lights Administration accused of bribery and corruption. The name of the late Secretary General of the Administration, Socrates Spiro Bey, was called out in Court, but this person, who is one of the accused, failed to put in an appearance, preferring to remain in Europe. The next ex-official of the Administration called was Attiah Effendi George, who is accused, together with Spiro Bey, of having received a bribe of £54 from Hafez Gobran in order to promote him to the post of chief storekeeper in the Administration. Attiah Effendi George was present. The first witness calledbnwas Hafez Gobran, who stated that he.did not wish to be appointed a clerk as Spiro and George suggested he should be. He asked to be promoted to chief storekeeper, so the two officials asked him for £100 to carry it through Finally he offered to pay £6". He paid first £20 to George and agreed to'pay the balance afterwards. The Court is still sitting as we go to press.

div.head:
CAIRO OPERA SEASON
HERODIADE
div.p: It is certainly a comfort after the ungainly fiasooes of last year to hear an opera decently performed, without obvious failures in orchestra, chorus and soloists. M. Poncet has evidently, though it is early in the season to judge, made a far more careful and judicious selection. As to the opera itself, Herodiade is hardly a piece for any but the baritones: the others have their chance, but it ts hardly a "obeval de bataille" for them. Perhaps the reason lies in the music. One cannot help feeling that Massenet was not in his element ; he was hungering, perhaps unconsciously after the light timeful satirical 'genre,' so apparent in his "Gongleur" or "Cendrillon," oppressed, it may be by the solemnity and even andacity of his subject. For a moment he rises to it, in the enrty of the priests, but then again the voluptuous, unsatisfied theme intrudes. As to the performance, the chorus were sound all through, as was the orchestra, though a trifle bald in parts. The prophet's entry was marred by overmuch noise in the wind instruments, and now and again in the chorus the altos tended to overshadow the sopranos, and produce a slightly crude effect. M. Soubeyran had as suggested, hardly that chance which should enable him to show the best of his voice, but in the dungeon scene (or it should be grotto) he rose to distinct excellence. His artticulation is notably good and clear, but occasionally his attack seems to hesitate. Mile Magne as Salome was admirable for technique, but also rather colourless : her voice sounded constrained at moments. Mr. Vallette as Herod rose to the part ; his fine resonant voice suited the part and the sentiment of the mosic, and he introduced shades and tones of passion and longing with real effect ; whether he will do as well in other parts remains to be seen. Mr. Loiglio was distinctly good as Phannel; he also has as fine voice, full, deep, and true. On the whole it was a very even, creditable performance, without any of the glaring massacres of downright bad singing that spoilt last years opera. The rest of the repertoire which is varied and interesting will doubtless show what the company can or cannot do. We may at least hope that it will be a distinct improvement.

div.head: THE REORGANIZATION OF THE CADRE
div.p: The Council of Ministers, at its meeting on Saturday, approved, on the proposal of the Minister of Finance the following arrangements regarding the reoranization of cadre.

1.—The credit of L.E. 72,000 inscribed on the budget of 1907 for the reorganisation of the cadre is divided among the State Adninistrations to serve to ameliorate the situation of the administrative and technical staff.
2.—The classes of the administrative cadre are fixed as follows :
4th class from L.E. 5 to 8
Assistant chef de bureau " " 24 to 28
Chef de Bureau " " 30 to 35
Assistant Director " " 37 to 43
Director " " 47 to 65

3.— By means of the sam allocated to it for its administrative staff to be drawn from the credit L.E. 72,000 each administration should first proceed to the claasification of its employees in the new cadre, the pay remaining over after this classification will serve the chief distribution for a better distribution of employments among the various classes of the cadre, according to the needs of service, in such manner as to increase the employments of the superior classes and to accord promotion on to the deserving employees.

4.—As regards the technical staff the chiefs of the Department will prepare the cadre which they judge best adapted to this staff within the limits of the portion of the credit of L.E. 72,000 at their disposal.
5.—The increases of salary and the promotions resulting from the present reorganization of the cadre will have a retroactive effect from 1st January 1907.

6.—The administrations at presnt regulated by the decrees of the 4the November 1893 and 24th June 1901 will alone benefit from the arrangements relative to the reorganization of the cadre. However, the staff whose condition has been already ameliorated by previous decisions will not be admitted to the benefits derivable from the present arrangement.
7.—The number of working hours is at fixed at six in the Ministries and Administrations where it is already less than this figure.

div.head: STRAMER MOVEMENTS.
div.p: The Mossi liner "Seti" sailed on Saturday afternoon last, for Liverpool via Malta with passengers, mails and general cargo, including 5, 135 bales of cotton.
The Canard S.S, "Cypria" arrived at Liverpool on Friday afternoon.
The S.S. "Cyprian Prince" with general cargo left Antwerp on the 6th inst., and is due to arrive at Alexandria on or about the 26th Deecember.

div.head: LETTER TO THE EDITOR
div.p: We do not hold ourselves responsible for the opinions expressed by our correspondents, but we wish, in a spirit of fait play to all, to permit---within certain necessary limits---free discussion.

div.head: COMPANIES IN EGYPT
div.p: TO THE EDITOR OF THE "EGYPTIAN GAZETTE."

Sir,—"Lex" has none too soon sounded the note of alarm as regards the anamalousposition of English companies in Egypr having alien boards It behoves, therefore, the shareholders in soi-disant English companies to be "up and doing." So far as we know, and English court has no power that the Mixed Tribanals have any such jurisdiction over the members of the board of an English company are free from any criminal responsibility. It is a notorious that, as a consequence of tis situation, many of these alien direrctors are simply the "dummies" of an individual or of a company having an axe to grind. Let me illustrate my meaning : According to English law, no director of a company can be directly or indirectly interested, pecuniarily or other wise, in any transaction supported by him as a member of the board. But, if he be an alien, he can, with inpunity, vote for the employment of the company's capital or reserves in the carrying out of schemes devised primarily for the profit of the wire-pullers whose interests he represents. Might I suggest that some clearer definition is necessary of the word "proprietor" in connection with the qualification shares of a director. The evident legal meaning of the word is that a director should have a real bona-fide interest in the company whose interests he controls. Is this always so, in fact
Yours truly,

Whatever the weather is elsewhere, no one Sean have any excuse for grumbling at it in Luxor, and no wonder that day by day fresh visitors are arriving from the North. Each day here is more beautiful than the last, from the rising up of the sun until the last moment of the fading away of its afterglow, there is no moment when Luxor is anything but gorgeous. The atmosphere is dry and invigorating, the temperature warm without being torrid, there is sight seeing and exercise for the healthy and energetic, and the most luxurious dolce far niente existence for the quasi-invalid and one of the finest and most complete hotels, at the command of all.

It is less than a year ago that the Winter Palace Hotel was opened to the public : and indeed it seems but yesterday that the workmen were swarming through it night and day to finish it in time for its inauguration. The approach which we remember combered with heaps of broken bricks and debris is now adorned with grass and flower beds; the wide waste behind the hotel is now taking shape As an ample garden; and before many weeks are over will be verdant with grass and rich in flowers.

Already there are many guests at the hotel which has been open now for several weeks Close upon a hundred covers were laid for dinner only yesterday, and many other arrivals are expected shortly. The old Luxor Hotel is to be re-opened shortly, and the Karnak on the river bank will again be used as an annexe by both the Winter Palace and the Luxor. The Savoy Hotel formerly under the direction of Mr. Runcovita is to be reopened under new management this season. It has its well established clientèle, and certainly its situation overhanging the river and away from the town are active points in its favour. The Rev. Mr Gross with Mrs. Gross has returned to his duties as chaplain again this season, and Dr. and Mrs. Saunders have been here ever since the opening of the hotel. Mrs. and the Misses Wanklyn too have been back for some weeks, and though Mrs. Wanklyn and one of her daughters have now left for Switzerland, the others will spend the remainder of the season most probably in Upper Egypt. Miss Bruce and Miss Dobie are also back in their old quarters, and many of the other habituees of Luxor are intending to return.

The Duke and Duchess of Devonshire with their party on board the dahabeah "Serapis" spent some time in the vicinity of Laxor on their way South. Mr. Robert Hickens is still here, living on board his dahabesh moored on the further side of the river ; but often coming on shore and frequently taking his meals at the Winter Palace. It is said that he does not intend going further south this trip; but in all probabilty will leisurely find his way down river to Cairo, storing the while many valuable impressions for future use.

Mr. Douglas Sladen is also gathering materials for a book on Egypt, for though a great traveller in other lands this is his first visit up the Nile. He is on his way to Khartoum accompanied by his wife, and by Miss Norma Lorrimer (also an authoress) and Mine Potter. They intend returning to Cairo about the middle of January and will in all probability remain there for the rest of the season. Mr and Ms. Holbach are expected in Laxor in a few days time. She is an authoress of no small ability and her latest book on Dalmatia is bigly spoken of Mr. Holbach is an adept in photography, and the reproductions of his pictures make most interesting illustrations to Mrs. Holbach's work.

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL
div.p: Our telegrams announce the death of Oscar II, King of Sweden, the great grandson of Napoleon's famous general, Bernadotte, who alone || of Napoleon's kinsmen and Marshals succeeded in founding permanent dynasty. King Oscar was born in 1829 and succeeded to the throne in 1872. He married in 1857 the daughter of the Duke of Nassau. His reign will always be eventful in the anuals of Scandinavia for the disruption of the dual Kingdom, the King having renounced all claims to Norway on the 26th October, 1905.

The new King of Sweden was born in 1868 and he married a Princess of Baden, The Crown Prince is the husband of Princess Margeret brConnaught, who was betrothed while in Egypt She will in the natural course of events be one day Queen of Sweden and will add another of the many grandchildren of Queen Victoria, who occupy European thrones. The list now includes the German Emperor, the Empress of Russia, the Queen of Norway, the Queen of Spain and will one day include the Queens of Roumania, Sweden, and Denmark.

The Duke of Brunswick lunched with the Khedive at Abdin Palace on Friday. Among the guests were Count Grote, Marshal of the German Court, 1st Equerry Boedecker, the officers of the Dake's suite, Count Berns dorff, German Diplomatic Agent, and the personnel of the Agency.
The Rumanian Consul-General in Egypt and Mme Padeano arrived at Alexandria yesterday from Constantinople.
Miralai E. A. Stanton Bey has left Khartoum on a short trip up the Nile for the purpose of recuperation after a slight indisposition.
Mr. Martin, who is travelling as correspondent for "The Times" on a special mission, has arrived at Khartoum.
Mr. Richard Croker, the well-known Ame rican politician, has left trelend for Cairo, where he will spend the winter. Mr. Croker does not intend to visit New York for the present.

Mr. Quinan, general manager of De Beers Dynamite Paetory at Somerset West, has left South Africa for Cairo. Mrs. Qainan and her sister, Miss Stanford, after visiting Johannesburg, joined the steamer at Delagos Bay. After spending the reason at Cairo, they proceed to London and Nauheim.

Messrs. W. B. Peat, Chartered Accountants whose Cairo representative is Mr . H. Victor Hall, have decided to open a branch at 9 Boulevard de Ramleh, Alexandria, which will be in charge of Mr. Gerald 8. Thompson, Chartered Accountant of London.

The remains of Mrs. Eliza Brookfield Percival of Fleming, Ramleh, (relief of the late John Brown Percival of Liverpool) were laid to rest on Saturday in the British Protestant Cemetery. Rosetta Gate, amid manifestations of Sorrow and regret. The Rev. H. P. Reid offered the committal prayer and benediction.

The following passengers left Cairo on Pri day by Cook P.S. "Hatasoo" for Upper Egypt :- Mr. and Mrs. de Haviland, Mr. Al and Mrs. Noble, Mr. and Mrs. Bonham Carter, Miss J: Bonham Carter, Mr. E Bonbam Carter, Capt. and Mr. McArthur Onslow, and Miss E. McArthur Onslow.

div.head: ALHAMBRA THEATRE JUVENILE OPERA COMPANY.
div.p: No more convincing proof of the popularity of this company of clever little artistes could be desired than she crowds of persons of all ages who assembled at the above theatre on Sunday afternoon to witness performance of "Fra Diavolo" absolutely taking possession of every available seat in the building, and judging from the hearty applause bestowed on each and every performer, many such full houses may be expected. Certainly the applause is fully merited for taking into consideration the tender ages of many of the children, their performances are little short of marvellous. Where all are so worthy of comment it would appear perhaps unfair to discriminate, but take for instance the dainty little Maria Ceccarelli and her gallant little companion Luigi Panotta. Could any : thing be more entertaining in its way than the delightful renderings of their respective parts in "The Geisha" as also the artistic performance of Signorina Castoldi and Signorina Math' in the same opera, or the truly wonderful rendering of the title role in "Frs Diavolo" by Guido Cursi, an eight year old.

Then again in Lucia de Lamermoor, the ease with which Signorina Dora Theor, a young lady still in her teens, sings the exceedingly difficult music allotted to her is astonishing. Prom a comedy point of view the palm falls to Alfred De Marco who certainly works hard, and gains his points, as Wun-Hi in "The Geisha." and he is closely followed by Arturo Marzani who created a deal of amusement out of the small part of Beppo in "Fra Diavolo." The choruses and dances are well executed and each opers is well staged. To-night will be produced Mascagni's "Cavalleria Rusticans" preceded by the first act of "Pipelet."

div.head: SPORT AND PLAY. K. S. C.
JUNIOR CHAMPIONSHIP POLO TOURNAMENT.
div.p: Three more ties in this championship were played off on Saturday. The defeat of the Coldstream Guards No 1 team was unexpected. Their second team on the other hand did better than was hoped for. The K.OS.B. No. I team had an easy tank against the Coldstream Guards No. III team.
FIRST MATCH

Coldstream Guards No. 9 team versus the K.O.S.B. No. 2 team, was quite a good game, The Guards went ahead at the start and were 4 love before their opponents registered goal, and eventually won 5 goals to I. Capt. Darell was stendy at back and Mr. Tritton hit well and kept his place. For the loners Mr. Furber played the best.
SECOND MATCH.

The Coldstream Guards team were upset by Mr. Tolleuiache being more or less useless from strained wrists and the other members of the team were off their game too. Whereas the 60th Rifles were at their best and played a dashing game ; they are beginning to get into their stride. Result, both Rifles 5 goals, Coldstream Guards 1 goal.
In the third match the k.O.S.B. No. I had an easy task with the Coldstream. Guarda No. III. winning by 11 goals to nil.
On Monday the semi-finals will be played, 1st match Goth Rifles v. Inniskilling Dragoons. 2nd match KOSB. No. 1, v. Coldstream Guards No. II.
The finals will be played on Wednesday.

div.head: HELOUAN'S NEW CASINO
div.p: The Egyptian Delta Light Railway Company issued invitations last week to the opening of the Helouan Casino on Saturday, and people were not slow to avail themselves of this opportunity of spending what proved to be a most thoroughly enjoyable afternoon, and the charming little gardens in which the casino stands were packed to overflowing during the afternoon. The band of the King's Own Soottish Borderers gave an excellent programme of music and tea was served both in the gardens themselves and in the marquee which had been erected at one side of them, while those who were desirous of refreshments of a stronger nature had every want supplied in the bar of the casino. The casino under its present conditions should prove a most welcome innovation to the inhabitants but only of Helouan, but also to residents and visitors to Cairo. The improvements which we have previously announced prove to have been made upon a most lavish scale, and the possession of this pleasure resort, which is absolutely unique in Cairo or its vicinity, cannot fail to draw many visitors to the town. later in the afternoon there was an excellent cinematograph display in the theatre which was greatly appreciated by the audience. The theatre itself has been re-decorated, and the stage enlarged, and we understand that the programme of entertainments which are to be held there are already complete for the entire sens on. In addition to the theatre and bar common to such places the casino also possesses spacious billiard rooms and here there are both English and French tables, and reading and card rooms for the use of general visitors, and a large balcony running round the theatre will be entirely reserved for ladies. The Committee has engaged first class orchestras to perform in the gardena four days a week during the Beason, and also on Thursday nights, when special entertainments are to be given in the Casino. We understand that it has been proposed to hold one big dance a week in the theatre of the Casino instead of the usual small ones at the various hotels of Helouan, but nothing has yet been settled as regards this, though the suggestion would seem to be a good one. The Delta Light Railway Company are to be congratulated upon the way in which they work for the public good. Their arrangements are carried out without a hitch, and it is sufficient to know that whether the occasion is the running of trains to the Citadel to view the various ceremonies which are yearly enacted there, or the formation of playground for the people, if it is the hands of the company above-mentioned comfort and regularity is assured.

div.head: TO-DAY'S EXCHANGE QUOTATIONS
div.p: *Less one per mille brokerage.
Alexandria, le 6 decembre 1907
It is seats announced that Zaluland is quiet. The military preparations, are not being relaxed.
(Reuter)
Colonels Clarke and Shepstone, accompanied by a magistrate and a doctor, have started for Usuta with a warrant for the arrest of Dini Zulu.
Colonel Mackenzie will remaimat Nongoma ready to act in the event of Dini Zulu resisting.
(Reuter)
The rebels are reported to be near Greytown. 50. reserves have entrained and proceeded: in their direction, The second reserves will be organised to morrow.
(Reuter)
The increase in the November imports amounts to £1,398,020 and the exports to £2,887,014 over the same period Inst year.
(Reuter)

Chamber of Deputies. Signor Carcano stated that there was a surplus in 1906-07 of 86,800,000 lire. The receipts had exceeded the estimates by 72,000,000, He estimated the net surpluses for 1907-08 as 29,000,000 and for 1908-09 26,000,000. The cash in the Treasury amounted to 478,000,000. (Reuter)
The Council of Emigration favours experi- mental colonisation of Italian farmers in West Australia. (Reuter)
King Oscar's condition is very grave. It is feared that he is sinking. (Reuter)
King Oscar is dead, The new King has taken the oath and taken the name of Gustave V.
(Havas)
The King is dead. (Reuter)
'Flags are hong at half mast throughout Norway as well as Sweden. (Reuter)
In its trials the new destroyer "Tartar" steamed 35 952 knots an hour. (Reuter)

The Congo cession treaty has been published. It transfers the sove¥eignty of the. State to Belgium with all rights and obligations. It respects the rights of third parties. It asks the Chambers to maintain and respect the Crown domain. The latter is & vast rich territory hitherto King Leopold's private property. The treaty is subject to ratification by the Chambers. (Reuter)
The India Council released 1,000,000 sove- reigns yesterday, (Reuter )
Mr. Cortelyou has only issued half of the Pansma Bonds and only two thirds of the Treasury Certificates. (Reuter)
President Roosevelt has definitively de slaved that he would under no circumstances consent to again stand for the presidency.(Reuter)
The mines at Monongah are on fire. It is believed that resoue is hopeless. (Reuter)
Untiring efforts to rescue the entombed men in the Monongah mine have been unavail- ing. There are at least 400 dead, including a number of Italians. 85 bodies have been recovered. (Reuter)

It is believed that the emigration question is practically settled, the Japanese Government verbally agreeing to a more rigid control of the character of the Japanese going to America and Canada (Reuter)

Mr. Tatt has left for Berlin and Hamburg, en route for America: In the course of an inter- view he denied that his tour had political significancexexcept as regards the Philippines the developmeut of which was satisfactory. There was no question of abandoning or selling them. (Reuter)
General Drude telegraphs that according to information received from Mogador, Mouley Hafid has left Marakesh on account of the attitude of the tribes who have combined with Abdel Aziz. (Havas)
The movement of the troops 'has been notified. (Havas)
The Sovereigns have retarned. (Havas)
Princess Marie Bonaparte has arrived. Prince George met her. (Havas)
M. Pallitres is indisposed and is keeping his room. (Havas)

Thé Chamber of Deputies has adopted an amendment taxing all Bourse transactions at the rate of 10 centimes per thousand francs, There is no innovation as regards the French rente. The Budget was then adoptéd. (Havas)

Trouble has arisen with the Cuottow Card- room Workers Amalgamated: Society. The Society threatens to call out 40,600 operatives in Lancashire if employers persist in the refusal to negociate'with the Amalgamated Society's officials at Oldham where the employees of two mills have gone on strike (Reuter)
An attempt has been made to blow up to Lieutenant Governor of -Bengal's train near Karagpur. The train was not derailed. The cause of the ontrage in unknown. (Reuter)

div.head: GOLD IN EGYPT.
div.p: COPE WHITEHOUSE'S REDIVIVUS.

Mr Cope Whitehouse iseveronthe warpath and his latest effusion appears in the "Journal of Commerce and Commercial Balletin", of New York. The statement that Lord Cromer announced the fact of such a large amount of gold existing in Egypt as "if it were a discovery", is manifestly absurd aa anybody knows, who has the slightest acquaintance with his Lordship's annual reports on Egypt. The letter is as follows:—
Editor: of the Journal of Commerce and Commercial Bulletin :

Sir, — In his recent speech at the Mansion House. Lord Cromer refers to the large amount of gold in Egypt, as if it were a discovery made by him within the last few months. But, in 1899, Baypt imported LE 4,678,290, andre- exported only L.E. 1,454,470. The pound sterling is 97.5, which gives the "Pound Egyp- tian" the value of $4.94. Therefore, the net import was about $15,000,000. In 1908 the import was LE. 6,276,806, and the export was LE. 1,771,708, with a notexcess of $20,507,093, As Egypt, north of Assouan, isa densely populated country of the size of inm, with six representatives of the Great Powers paid $10,000 a year apiece to watch its finances,and a Ministry of Finance with 356 Europeans, at whose head was Lord Milner daring his stay in Egypt, the amount of gold in the country is more easily obtainable than that of any other country in the world. These facts, however, were carefully concealed for motives which were only too apparent. Lord Cromer refers to the probable release of hoarded gold throngh the right to issue notes given to the so-called Bank of Egypt, This bank has an Egyptian charter, and is international in ita directors, who represent eyery religion except Islam, with only three English names out or seventeen. On January 1, 1905, it borrowed from the Goverriment LLB. 8,967,292 in gold, or say, abont $19,500,000, As Lord Cromer himself puts it, with thinly veiled sarcasm, the bank had "in the conduct of its basiness made laudable efforts to assist the Government" It issued "paper currency" (Parl. Rep. 1906, p. 52.)to the amount of (December $1, 1906) L.E. 2,315,889. As the notes of issue were only secured to the extent of a moiety in gold, the bank held L.E. 1,157,694, or say, $5,780,000, as against nearly $20,000,000 which had been withdrawn from the sub-treasury on January 1, 1905, onder the terms of & convention annéxed to that Anglo-Frenoli entente whose mysterious operations have never been fully disclosed. In the single month of October, 1906, Egypt imported $28,150,000 withoat increasing its currency by any appreciable amount.

According to the consular report issued in Washington on November 1, 1907, it appears that Egypt imported, in 1906, cereals, flour, vegetablespnd fruit to the value of $15,657,845, of which $403,700 represented the value corn (maize) from the United States. In consequence of the deterioration due tothe impoverishment of the soil of Egypt and the practical destruc- tion of the water supply from the White Nile daring the inundation period, by the channels, which have been cut to the south of Khartum, it would seem that the opening up of direct relations between the cotton planters and the United States, with the sale of bread- stuffs for gold only, might securé a supply of at least $20,000,000 during the next four months. From July, 1, 1875, to November 1, 1877, Egypt appears to have lost in gold and silver, coin and bullion, over $90,000,000. The method adopted was somewhat complex, although parts of it were dufficiently simple. Any man known tobave any considerable sum of bullion or specie in his possession was "required by the European representatives of various banks and bankers to surrender it to them without com- pénaation, The only equivalent which can now be offered other than breadstaffs is land. It is evident that unless the Government should immediately permit the execution of the Raiyan drainage canal and reservoir so as to reclaim the swamps lying between the cultivated lands of the delta and the Mediterranean, many years must elapse before this resource will be a its disposal.
Cope Whitehouse.
November 15, 1907.

div.head: WEAKNESS AND EXHAUSTION REPAIRED. DR. WILLIAMS' PINK PILLS A REMEDY FOR AILING CHILDREN.
div.p: Mme. Caspeele, who lives at 19 Olytstraat, Ghent, recently made the following statement to an agent for Dr. William Pink Pills for Pale People.

"My daughter Sophie incontestably owes her present good health to Dr. Williams' Pink Pills. The girl, who was em- ployed in a spinning mill, stood in need of all her strength, but she was as weak as she could be. In addition to this she had no appetite, and she digested her food badly, while her healthy complexion completely disappeared. She tried several treatments with no success; none of them gave her the strength which she required. It is to be hoped that this testimonial will fall be- neath the notice of any parents whose children's condition causes them disquietude. It these children are treated with Dr. Williams' Pink Pills there will be fur- ther cures in view, for these pills strengthen the patient, impart blood give a healthy com- plexion, tonity the nor ves, re-awaken the appe- ttite, improve the diges- tion, and dissipate pain. Dr. Williams' Pink Pills for Pale People are a cure for anemia, chloro- sis, neurasthenia, gene- ral weakness, stomach troubles, sick headache, neuralgia, sciatica and rheumatism.

div.head: ARMY AND NAVY
div.p: The battleships "Goliath," "Canopus" and "Ocean" are to:be despatched in the order named, when their re-fit is completed, to relieve the battleships"Formidable," "Implacable" and "Implacable" on the Mediterranean station.

Captain F.S. Miller, who has been latterly studying at the War College, has been selected 'for the command of the "Goliath," and will hoist his pennant on the Sth prox. Captain Miller is a captain of 1903, and he joined as a cadet in 1877, and at his examination took four firsts and the Shadwell Testimonial. He was a middy of the battleship "Monarch" at the bombardment of Alexandria, and commanded the gatling gun party landed after the bombardment (medal with clasp, and Khedive's Star.)

The home battalions of the Coldstream Guards have been laid under contribution for another draft for the 3rd Battalion, at Cairo, whither it will be despatched early in January. This does not look as if the Anny Council intended to disband the 3rd Battalion at an early date.

Everyone feels that Mr. Haldane's scheme is the last ditch of voluntary enlistment for the upkeep of the Imperial Army. If the scheme fail, and there is guarantee that it will not, there is nothing but conscription left for it. It is simply staving off the evil day. Mr. Haldane's scheme, according to his own words, will take ten years to mature Many things un- looked for will happen in that decade.
A correspondent of the Royal Inniskilling Fusiliers (27th) to the "Army and Navy Gazette" writes trom Crete.

"If what is rumoured be true, our stay in the Mediterranean will not bea prolonged one. The battalion came here in March last, and has been on friendly terms with those among whom it finds itself temporarily doing duty ; but it will not be sorry when the order comes for it to go East. It has a sort of local connec- tion with India through its 2nd Batn., the old 108th, and it has been so long absent from that land of true soldiering that it may be considered to possess a preference claim. The Mediter- ranean isall well and good in its way, but it has not the attractions ofa good Indian station."

Captain F.M.C. Trench, Royal Field Artil- lery, who has just joined the Egyptian Army, is a smart young officer who learned soldiering in the best of all schools—active service. He was a subaltern of the 69th Field Battery, then in Natal, when the war broke out in South Africa, and he was present at the actions of Talana Hill and Lombard's Kop, and the subsequentdefence of Ladysmith After the siege was raised he served on the staff as aide de camp to a divisional officer. He was twice mentioned in despatches, and received the queen's medal with six clasps.

Brevet Major G.K. Ansell, 6th Inniskilling Dragooons, on vacating the appointment of Brigade Major of the Third Cavalry Brigade, has been iso of to re-join his regiment at once, instead of in January next.
Lieutenant Colonel W.J. Baker, Royal Army Medical Corps, has been placed under orders to go to Egypt early in January next.

The question of the employment of Position and Range Finder artificers of the Machinery Artificers Section, Army Ordnance Corps, has been under consideration by the Army Coun- cil, and it has been decided that such artificers shall in the future, in common with others of the Machinery Artificers Section Army Ordnance Corps, be under the control of the local Chief Ordnance officers, by whom they will be allotted to officers commanding Royal Artillery for such periods as are necessary. This allotment is to be made locally. When actually engaged in repairing or adjusting po- sition finding and depression range finding instruments the artificers will be under the orders of the officer commanding Royal Artil- lery, but when not required for position and range finding work they will be employed on ordinary armament work under the Inspector of Ordnance Machinery.
